comments.text: Your lessons are awesome and I rather enjoy the simplicity of your explanations. Thank you!
comments.author: @DrummerX2010

comments.text:
For odd time sigs, I found it better to break them up into groups of 2 3 and 4... For example, you could/should count 1 2 3 4/1 2 3 or 123/1234, that gives the music/song a more solidified feel.
For example, only tapping your foot on 1 do 1 2 3 1 2 and you can immediately feel a groove as opposed to tapping on 1 and 4 and counting to 5, even though they're the same thing. 7 grouped 3 and then 4 is also very natural, and you can tap your foot ever odd number... counting this way makes it alot easier.

I'm greek and it's how I learned to count in our odd songs (5/7/9's). In slower songs you can count to 5 if you're doing 5's or 9's, but keeping it to 2, 3 and 4 makes it much more digestible.

As an exercise, listen to the 7/8 part in tom sawyer by rush and try counting in in 4 then 3 vs 1-7
comments.author: @vasiliscond9433

comments.text:
To anyone trying to get this into their brain, I highly recommend the Indian Konnakol system of singing. It's made up of syllables like "taka", "dimi", "tom", etc, which represent different lengths, either a triplet or a quarter note. And you can easily combine these to create all sorts of rhythms. 

Never thought I'd be able to sing the rhythm part of a Meshugah song but here we are. 21/17 time signature? Pff, piece of cake. 

Now, playing it on anything other that a practice pad is a different question haha.
comments.author: @steve17
